tweet:
And all of us need to be a bit more patient and empathetic.

The spectrum is certainly wide and diverse.  I can only speak to my experiences as his mom, but I‚Äôm always happy to answer questions. The more we demystify autism, the faster we can bring about that acceptance. (5/5)

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: Employers need to accept and understand that neurodivergent individuals have a lot to contribute, and are worthy of certain accommodations being made for them. First responders need to be aware that people with autism don‚Äôt always react as expected in traumatic situations.  (4/5)

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: I won‚Äôt debate about why only marginalized stories should be considered #ownvoices. Its intent is to give voice to those who‚Äôve been underrepresented in publishing. Writers not falling under the term should feel privileged to have never been muted because of who they are.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: If you're not sure your book could be classified as #ownvoices, but feel your experiences are relevant, then you should address that in the bio portion of your query. Just because you're not using that term, doesn't mean your experiences will be invalidated by the agent.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: Since I'm getting a lot of questions, I should add that there are a lot of grey areas. And not every publishing professional will have the exact same answer for specific examples. But it's in the author's best interest not to use that term if you're just not sure....

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @KatieBWrites Personally, I think disorders and conditions that have been stigmatized could be classified as #ownvoices, so yes, in this case I think it's applicable.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @JackieKhalilieh Then no, the book isn't #ownvoices if the character isn't part of that same community.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @JATauthor There are certainly grey areas, but personally, I don't feel that example should be classified as #ownvoices. Others might feel differently.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @MostlyMcLeod There are certainly some grey areas, but personally, I think it's best to reserve it for conditions that tend to be stigmatized.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: Seeing a lot of queries incorrectly using #ownvoices as descriptor. You should only use that term if you are a writer from a marginalized community depicting a character from that same community. If you're a dentist writing about a dentist, that doesn't make your book #ownvoices.

tweet: @MochaSarah @BookEndsJessica That's a hard question to answer. It can be a million different things. But I really like to feel like I'm thrown into the middle of the action, and still get a sense of who the character(s) is, without being bombarded by backstory and introspection.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @101mystic @BookEndsJessica Dyslexia won't hold you back from publication (I have a bestselling client who's dyslexic), but if grammar feels like a struggle, then consider finding a critique partner, beta reader or hiring a professional to help you polish your work before sending it to agents #askagent

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @vsam90807591 @BookEndsJessica It's best to have the most polished manuscript possible before submitting to agents, but not absolutely necessary to pay a professional to get you there.  Some agents are more editorial than others, but it's always a good idea to send them your strongest, cleanest work. #askagent

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @viggyhampton @BookEndsJessica Agents assume you're submitting widely, so no need.  At most agencies, like BookEnds, it's best though not to send to more than one agent in the same agency at the same time.

tweet: #querytip #pubtip: Recently, the most common reason I've  rejected submissions is due to info-dumping early in the book. Remember you need to hook your reader first. More information can be parceled out later.  Also, just be sure to write tightly. Use words economically.

tweet: @CherryColaZing @MelissaLaurenE Writing is a creative process, but by deciding to get published, you've made the decision to find a market for your book.  In order to be successful, you have to give some thought to who your readers will be and why they'll want to buy your book.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: #querytip If your query blurb is overly long, it will seem that your book doesn't have a clear focus/or you don't have a clear idea of how to market it.  If your query blurb is too short or focuses only on  character, then it can appear that the story, itself, is weak.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: #querytip Taking time to craft your query blurb is important. Agents base their decision both on what your book is about AND your ability to describe it. We want to see that you a) know the hook of your book b) can show there's a clear plot line and c) use your words wisely.

tweet: @AnastasiaKBond It's best to make your query as specific as possible.  Who knows? Maybe they read the query so quickly because they saw that you mentioned those things and prioritized it. So far it may have ended in rejection, but keep trying. Making a connection with the agent is a plus.

description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @CaitlinLaRue Honestly, the biggest factor for me, outside of loving the manuscript that's been submitted, is hearing what they plan to work on next.  Seeing that they have more fresh ideas and have thought about building a brand for themselves.  Not just being focused on this one project.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @ICT_Pinup @bookendslit or say "for romance lovers waiting for a tortured hero like Kaz in SIX OF CROWS," or somesuch, you can make it work. 2/2

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @ICT_Pinup @bookendslit Depends on how you word it.  If writing adult rom & use SIX OF CROWS as comp title w/i qualifier, sounds like you don't understand the market. But if you use a 2nd comp that IS in your genre SIX OF CROWS meets THE HATING GAME 1/2

tweet: @peery_brett @bookendslit They're not necessary, but I find them helpful and attention-getting. Having a hook is important, so if you're presenting that upfront in your logline then you're showing you have one and you've thought about how to market the book.

name: Kim Lionetti

tweet: @rainforestgardn I'm certainly eager to find more neurodiverse authors and characters! With the success of The Kiss Quotient and others, publishers have definitely opened up to more representation of autistic individuals. I know it's especially a goal for @NaomisLitPix and me.

tweet: @ElizabethWFox At @bookendslit we answer every query, but not all agencies do.  Check each individual website for submission guidelines.  If guidelines say they respond to every query and the window has ended on usual response time, don't be afraid to send it again.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @ParaLiterature @dmsreadwrite @BookEndsJessica @AgentJessicaA @NaomisLitPix @wensday95 Traditional pubs had a hard time selling NA, mostly because of pricing issues. The big NA successes were mostly self-pubbed and offered at low price points. Traditional pubs have overhead & printing costs, so can't offer same competitive prices. Sales just weren't there. 2/2

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @ParaLiterature @dmsreadwrite @BookEndsJessica @AgentJessicaA @NaomisLitPix @wensday95 YA vs NA is really about the age of the protagonist.  YA is usually 15-18 (preferable 17), and NA is college-age or slightly older.  Honestly, there's some YA w/ sex (though usually not overly hot), so I don't think that's a good indicator. 1/2

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @7daysaweekblog @BookEndsJessica @AgentJessicaA @NaomisLitPix @wensday95 I think you're probably safest in the 3 to 5 page range. #askagent

tweet: I need to go back to the piles on my desk.  Thanks for a great #askagent session and feel free to tweet me directly with any other questions.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @kevsgiles @BookEndsJessica @AgentJessicaA @NaomisLitPix @wensday95 I don't know how that specific series is handled, but generally, series like those are often commissioned by the editors, who then reach out to certain agents/authors they know.  #askagent

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @brooketaylorboo @BookEndsJessica It depends on the genre and how dependent the manuscript's story is on future books. #askagent

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @dmsreadwrite @BookEndsJessica @AgentJessicaA @NaomisLitPix @wensday95 A few years ago, publishers really made a push in the New Adult market, but unfortunately didn't see a lot of success, especially in print.  As a result, it's definitely harder to pitch these days. #askagent

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @markdsalzwedel You should think about what an agent could bring to the table after the deal too.. Contract negotiation, middle-man for the less pleasant conversations w/ publisher, career strategizing, growing your brand... A lot comes after the offer. Something to consider. #askagent

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @KolinMofield Novels are all about the execution, so it's really hard to give any kind of opinion on an idea alone, unless, of course it's a client we already know well and understand their strengths, et. #askagent

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @katherin_e_hunt @BookEndsJessica @bookendslit @AgentJessicaA @NaomisLitPix Self-edited applies too!  Just make sure it's not your first draft that hasn't been polished. #askagent

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @justine_manzano It's really hard to say without knowing the book.  I'm not an anti-prologue person.  If you feel it's needed, then go with your gut. #askagent

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @KMaximick @BookEndsJessica I always want to see comp titles, as long as they really tell me something substantive.  I want the comp to tell me who would like your book...the same audience as... Use meaningful titles. If they're huge bestselling authors like JK Rowling, it's actually less helpful.

name: Kim Lionetti
description: Literary agent of adult and young adult fiction. Autism mom. British period drama addict. Gosling aficionado. Penn State alum. She/her.
tweet: @rscottmather @BookEndsJessica For sure. Movies, tv, anything with an audience, because that's what we're really looking for.  The comp is really to tell me more about the audience for your book.  #askagent

tweet: #pubtip Don't immediately accept an offer of rep, even if it's your dream agent. You'll do yourself a disservice. Take a week to contact other agents. See if there's more interest, even if just to put first offer into context. Don't give up the opportunity to weigh all options.
